added_lines: import uuidfrom neutron.agent.ovsdb.native.commands import BaseCommandclass AddFakeChassisCommand(BaseCommand): """Add a fake chassis in OVN SB DB for functional test.""" def __init__(self, api, name, ip, **columns): super(AddFakeChassisCommand, self).__init__(api) self.name = name self.ip = ip self.columns = columns def run_idl(self, txn): encap_row = txn.insert(self.api._tables['Encap']) encap_row.type = 'geneve' encap_row.ip = self.ip self.columns.update({'encaps': [encap_row.uuid]}) row = txn.insert(self.api._tables['Chassis']) row.name = self.name for col, val in self.columns.items(): setattr(row, col, val) self.monitor_nb_idl_con = connection.Connection( self.monitor_nb_idl_con.start() self.monitor_nb_db_idl = self.monitor_nb_idl_con.idl """num_attempts = 0 while num_attempts < 3: try: self.monitor_sb_idl_con = connection.Connection( self.ovsdb_server_mgr.get_ovsdb_connection_path( db_type='sb'), 60, 'OVN_Southbound') self.monitor_sb_idl_con.start() self.monitor_sb_db_idl = self.monitor_sb_idl_con.idl break except Exception: LOG.exception(_LE("Error connecting to the OVN_Southbound DB")) num_attempts += 1 time.sleep(1)""" def nb_idl_transaction(self, fake_api, check_error=False, log_errors=True, **kwargs): return impl_idl.Transaction(fake_api, self.monitor_nb_idl_con, 60, check_error, log_errors) def sb_idl_transaction(self, fake_api, check_error=False, log_errors=True, **kwargs): return impl_idl.Transaction(fake_api, self.monitor_sb_idl_con, 60, self.monitor_nb_idl_con = None self.monitor_sb_idl_con = None class TestOVNSbFunctionalMixin(object): """Mixin for OVN SB functional test. Must be used with TestOVNFunctionalBase. """ def add_fake_chassis(self, host, physical_nets=None): physical_nets = physical_nets or [] fake_api = mock.MagicMock() fake_api.idl = self.monitor_sb_db_idl fake_api._tables = self.monitor_sb_db_idl.tables bridge_mapping = ",".join(["%s:br-provider%s" % (phys_net, i) for i, phys_net in enumerate(physical_nets)]) name = uuid.uuid4().hex with self.sb_idl_transaction(fake_api, check_error=True) as txn: external_ids = {'ovn-bridge-mappings': bridge_mapping} txn.add(AddFakeChassisCommand(fake_api, name, "172.24.4.10", external_ids=external_ids, hostname=host)) return name
deleted_lines: self.monitor_idl_con = connection.Connection( self.monitor_idl_con.start() self.monitor_nb_db_idl = self.monitor_idl_con.idl def idl_transaction(self, fake_api, check_error=False, log_errors=True, **kwargs): return impl_idl.Transaction(fake_api, self.monitor_idl_con, 60, self.monitor_idl_con = None

commit_message:
Don't pass value_specs when creating internal port

When we create the internal port on a nova server, we shouldn't pass
value_specs when specifying extra properties, as it's an internal
dictionary which is not accepted by the API.

Change-Id: I0bb4407e89b5575dbaf8f198402e0926b550224d
Closes-Bug: #1607364
(cherry picked from commit 2245aa117e8fae5710244ab1182b499aba82b339)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/85/356985/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Noop run support

Specify any set of tasks, nodes or cluster where to run Noop with
--noop option.

Implements blueprint: puppet-noop-run

Depends-on: 8f7fbaee723974dff3d5313ccd486d2dc8475781

Change-Id: I6c1ad22cdabfd3ff8028e5fa2788f30a1063c041

commit_message:
Add a nested_depth argument to poll_for_events

This will allow library calls to have more control over the depth of
events which are logged.

Change-Id: Iecb8c89745f916c50936e013a62176d586cfcc63
Closes-Bug: #1616682

commit_message:
py3:Rmove six.iteritems/iterkeys in python-senlinclient

1As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using six.iteritems/keys achieve
iterators. We can use dict.items/keys instead, as it will return iterators in
PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys will more readable.
2In py2, the performance about list should be negligible, see the link [2].

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I75d12f56821666ebaec8350acba3a5fc29957f1e

added_lines: class ValidatePolicy(command.ShowOne): """Validate a policy.""" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ValidatePolicy") def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(ValidatePolicy, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument( '--spec-file', metavar='<spec-file>', required=True, help=_('The spec file used to create the policy') ) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)", parsed_args) senlin_client = self.app.client_manager.clustering spec = senlin_utils.get_spec_content(parsed_args.spec_file) attrs = { 'spec': spec, } policy = senlin_client.validate_policy(**attrs) formatters = { 'spec': senlin_utils.json_formatter } columns = [ 'created_at', 'data', 'domain', 'id', 'name', 'project', 'spec', 'type', 'updated_at', 'user' ] return columns, utils.get_dict_properties(policy.to_dict(), columns, formatters=formatters)

commit_message:
Skip post-config based on t-h-t flag

If the ManagedEndpoints flag comes from t-h-t as an output, then we
can assert that the keystone services and endpoints are managed by
puppet, and thus we can skip the post-config step.

Change-Id: Ibbbe1e016e7e47ea5577de33c5a11d4088811616
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/16/353316/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _endpoints_managed(self, stack): for output in stack.to_dict().get('outputs', {}): if output['output_key'] == 'ManagedEndpoints': # NOTE(jaosorior): We don't really care about the value as # long as the key is there. return output['output_value'] return False if not self._endpoints_managed(stack): self._keystone_init(overcloud_endpoint, overcloud_ip_or_fqdn, parsed_args, stack) else: self.log.debug("Keystone endpoints and services are managed by " "puppet. Skipping post-config.")

commit_message:
Deperecate apt-mirror element

There are upstream methods for setting a mirror which are much more
flexible, lets just document and point users at them.

Change-Id: I442e4695d56086932403fb5893da89ead203c86d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/86/358786/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ -n "${UBUNTU_MIRROR:-}" ]; then echo "DEPRECATED WARNING: Use of apt-mirror element is deprecated. See http://docs.openstack.org/developer/diskimage-builder/elements/ubuntu/README.html and http://docs.openstack.org/developer/diskimage-builder/elements/apt-sources/README.html for alternate methods of setting an ubuntu mirror." fi

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import json import logging from cliff import lister class ListPlans(lister.Lister): """List overcloud deployment plans""" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ListPlans") def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)" % parsed_args) workflow_client = self.app.client_manager.workflow_engine execution = workflow_client.action_executions.create( 'tripleo.plan_list') try: json_results = json.loads(execution.output)['result'] except Exception: self.log.exception("Error parsing JSON %s", execution.output) json_results = [] result = [] for r in json_results: result.append((r,)) return (("Plan Name",), result)

commit_message:
Add spec for active-active

This specification contains a high-level description of a proposed
architecture for handling an active-active topology within Octavia.

Moved Distributor to new document.
Captured the comments from Mitaka mid-cycle.

Updated active-active-topology per latest comments.

Major update to active-active-distributor per latest comments.

More updates per comments

Change-Id: Ifc2d618a979fd0eb822f2cba4b759ab6ade7793f
Co-Authored-By: Eran Raichstein <eranra@il.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dean Lorenz <dean@il.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Stephen Balukoff <stephen@balukoff.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/39/234639/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode **Note:** Items marked with [P2] refer to lower priority features to be designed / implemented only after initial release. =============================== Auto-Scaled, N+1 Amphorae Setup =============================== @TODO change this https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/autoscaledamphorae This blueprint describes how Octavia implements an auto-scaled loadbalancer (LB) solution that is both elastic and highly-available. It presents the high-level service topology and suggests high-level code changes to the current code base to realize this scenario. In a nutshell, an elastic cluster of amphorae provides an LB service using an existing clustering solution. For the initial implementation, the proposal is to base on Heat Auto-Scaling. Discussion regarding other possible choices and/or pluggable design will be held separately; Heat-based design is presented throughout this document. This blueprint uses terminology defined in Octavia glossary when available, and defines new terms to describe new components and features as necessary. Problem description =================== A tenant should be able to start a highly-available, elastic loadbalancer for the tenant's backend services as follows: * The operator should be able to configure an auto-scaled topology through an Octavia configuration file or [P2] through a Neutron flavor, which the loadbalancer shall support. Octavia shall support an auto-scaled topology in addition to the topologies that it currently supports. * In an auto-scaled topology, a cluster of two or more amphorae shall host a replicated configuration of the load-balancing services. Octavia will manage this cluster of amphorae as an elastic, highly-available service using a Heat-controlled pool of resources. * The *Amphora Cluster* shall provide the load-balancing services and support the configurations that are supported by a single amphora topology, including L7 load-balancing, SSL termination, etc. * The auto-scaled topology shall support various amphora types and implementations; including, virtual machines, [P2] containers, and bare-metal servers. * The operator should be able to configure the high-availability requirements for the load-balancing services. The operator shall be able to specify a minimal number of healthy amphorae that must exist in the load-balancing cluster. If the number of healthy amphorae drops under the desired number, Octavia shall automatically and seamlessly create and configure a new amphora and add it to the cluster. [P2] The operator should be further able to define that the Amphora Cluster shall be (physically) allocated on resources from multiple availability zones. * The number of amphorae in the load-balancing cluster shall elastically adjust to match the workload on the load-balancing services. Upon increase in demand, new amphorae shall be created and added to the cluster to provide a minimal configurable quality-of-service (QoS) for the load-balancing services. Upon decrease in demand, some amphorae shall be removed from the cluster and deleted, minimizing resource usage while still providing load-balancing services at the desired QoS. * OpenStack Ceilometer will be used to monitor the QoS provided by the Amphora Cluster; and OpenStack Heat will be used to manage the Amphora Cluster and apply scale-up and scale-down policies. The operator shall be able to configure and control the desired quality-of-service for the load-balancing services through Ceilometer alarms (`Ceilometer::Alarm`) and Heat scaling policies (`Heat::ScalingPolicy`). * An amphora cluster will collectively act to serve as a single logical loadbalancer as defined in the Octavia glossary. Octavia will seamlessly distribute incoming external traffic among the amphorae in the cluster. To that end, Octavia will employ a *Distributor* component that will forward external traffic towards the managed amphora instances. Conceptually, the Distributor provides an extra level of load-balancing for an auto-scaled Octavia application, albeit a simplified one. Octavia should be able to support several Distributor implementations (e.g., software-based and hardware-based). * The detailed design of the Distributor component will be described in a separate document. [P2] Octavia will support a highly-available Distributor implementation and [P2] optionally support multiple per-tenant Distributors. - @TODO Agree on naming of Distributor. High-level Topology Description ------------------------------- * The following diagram illustrates the Auto-scaled topology: :: Distributor Tenant Internet Network Network (world) (provider) (internal)            Tenant  Router floating IP   Service   to loadbalancer  IP  Amphora  IP   (1)   VIP  dist (1) int.          MGMT    Tenant      IP  Service   VIP Distri-  IP     (2)    butor dist         IP  Amphora  IP    MGMT    dist (2) int.   Tenant   IP    Service    MGMT    (3)     IP          Heat        Controller          IP  Amphora  IP   dist (k) int.        Tenant   Octavia   MGMT  Service   LBaaS   IP   (m)   Controller       Management Amphora Cluster Back-end Pool Network 1..k 1..m * An example of high-level data-flow: 1. Internet clients access a tenant service through an externally visible floating-IP (IPv4 or IPv6) 2. If IPv4, a router maps the floating IP into a loadbalancer's internal VIP on a (multi-tenant) provider network. 3. The (multi-tenant) Distributor distributes incoming connections over the tenant's Amphora Cluster, by forwarding each new connection opened with a loadbalancer's VIP to a front-end MAC address of an amphora in the cluster (layer-2 forwarding). The front-end IPs of the amphorae are allocated on the provider's (multi-tenant) Distributor network. 4. Each amphora load-balances the incoming connections to the back-end pool of tenant servers, by forwarding each external request to a member on the tenant network. The amphora also performs SSL termination if configured. * The following diagram illustrates the Auto-scaled topology with multiple tenants and multiple availability zones: :: Distributor Tenant Internet Network Network (world) (provider) (internal)           Tenant A Router floating IP   Service   to loadbalancer  IP  Amphora A IP  (1)   VIP A and VIP B  dist A(1) int.          MGMT   Tenant A     IP  Service        (2)         VIP     IP  Amphora A IP   A  Distri-  IP  dist A(2) int.  Tenant A  VIP butor dist    Service   B     MGMT    (3)      IP     MGMT     avail. zone A1  IP   - - - - - - - - - - - -  - - - - - - -     avail. zone A2    IP  Amphora A IP  dist A(k-1) int.       Tenant A  MGMT  Service     IP    (m-1)              IP  Amphora A IP Tenant A   dist A(k) int. Service      (m)   MGMT      IP     tenant A   - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -     tenant B   IP  Amphora B IP    dist B(1) int.  Tenant B    Service   MGMT    (1)     IP          Heat        Controller          IP  Amphora B IP  dist B(q) int.       Tenant B  Octavia   MGMT  Service   LBaaS   IP   (r)   Controller       Management Amphora Clusters Back-end Pool Network A(1..k), B(1..q) A(1..m),B(1..r) * Both tenants A and B share the Distributor and the Distributor network; that is, the Distributor listens on both loadbalancers' VIPs and forwards to either A's or B's amphorae. * The amphorae and the back-end (tenant) networks are not shared between tenants. * A's amphorae and back-end servers are distributed across two availability zones. Problem Details --------------- * The operator should be able to configure QoS metrics via Ceilometer alarms - Direct performance measurements on the amphorae in the cluster, such as average CPU, [P2] memory, or network utilization. - [P2] Network traffic measurements on the front-end network of the Amphora Cluster, such as number of connections, queue length, or bandwidth. * The operator should be able to configure different types of triggers for the Ceilometer alarms - Threshold-based triggers; namely, a given metric is aggregated (e.g., averaged) over a given time period and an alarm is fired if an operator-defined threshold is crossed. - [P2] Schedule-based triggers; namely, an alarms is fired at operator-define times (e.g., nighttime). - [P2] Manual triggers; namely, an alarm is fired through operator API. * The operator should be able to configure different types of scale-up and scale-down policies, as supported by Heat. * The operator should be able to configure different types of algorithms for the Distributor. All algorithms should provide per-flow affinity to allow TLS termination at the amphora. - Initial Distributor reference implementation shall support round-robin with flow affinity. The Distributor will perform per loadbalancer L2 forwarding. * Octavia should support different Distributor implementations, similarly to its support for different amphora types. This means the Octavia controller should make use of an abstract Distributor driver. [P2] Octavia should support both software and hardware based Distributor. [P2] The software-based Distributor can be a container, a VM, bare-metal server, or even a to-be-defined function of an upstream SDN solution. * Octavia controller shall seamlessly configure any newly created amphora ([P2] including peer state synchronization, if needed) and shall reconfigure the other solution components (e.g., Neutron, Ceilometer) as needed. The controller shall further manage all amphora life-cycle events. * [P2] The operator should be able to configure deployment over multiple availability zones. In this type of configuration, both the back-end pool and the Amphora Cluster are deployed on multiple availability zones. There should be zone locality, namely, amphorae shall forward to members in their own zone only. - Initial reference implementation shall support placement of amphorae in a single availability zone. No support for back-end members in multiple zones and no support for zone locality. * The Distributor and its back-end Distributor network shall support multi-tenancy. See [security implications](#security_impact) below. Proposed change =============== The auto-scaled loadbalancers require the following high-level changes: * Amphora changes - Updated amphora image to support auto-scaled topology. Front-end has both a unique IP (to allow addressing by Distributor) and a VIP. VIP should not answer ARP requests (all amphorae in a single cluster listen on same VIP). Amphorae should continue to have a management IP on the LB Network so Octavia can configure them. Amphorae should also generally support hot-plugging interfaces into back-end tenant networks as they do in the current implementation. [P2] Finally, the amphora configuration may need to be changed to prevent synchronized decisions by all amphorae in the cluster. - Extend data model to support auto-scaled amphora. This is somewhat similar to VRRP support. Each amphora needs to store its IP and port on the Distributor network. Each amphora should store a reference to its cluster Heat stack. (@TODO perhaps use the vrrp fields for this, there is no need for the ha_ip info and role). The status should be interpreted as referring to the amphora only and not the load-balancing service (@TODO when do we change the status of the loadbalancer). [P2] There should be references to the Distributor(s); in case there are several Distributor instances (it may be possible to deduce this information from the Distributor network). - Extend controller worker to support asynchronous execution of the amphora configuration flows. This is required as Heat can decide when to add or remove an amphora. The flows do not need much change (beyond those implied by the changes in the data model), since the post-creation/pre-deletion configuration of each amphora is unchanged. - Extend controller worker to include Amphora (de-)registration with Distributor. - All the amphorae in the cluster shall replicate the same listeners, pools, and TLS configuration, as they do now. - @TODO Do we need to extend both the Amphora REST and ssh APIs? (e.g. to toggle ARPing of the VIP). Can we limit support only to the REST driver? * Compute driver for the auto-scaled topology *new* - Add an auto-scaled topology to the topology types. - Add a new driver to support creation of an amphora (cluster) via Heat instead of Nova. Heat stack will create a `Heat::AutoScalingGroup` resource to spawn `Nova::Server` resources based on Ceilometer Alarms [P2] in configured Availability zones. - Heat will orchestrate creation and deletion of amphora instances to manage the cluster. Nova (@TODO or Heat) post-creation and pre-deletion hooks will be used to invoke Octavia post-creations/pre-deletion amphora flows. [P2] E.g., handle graceful amphora removal, delay actual removal until existing connections are terminated or some timeout has passed. - Change the flow of LB creation. The driver shall create a Heat template for each new loadbalancer. It should wait for minimum number of amphorae in the cluster to be ready before it can update the readiness of the loadbalancer. This depends on the high-availability configuration given by the operator (@TODO handle partially-healthy states). [P2] It may require a minimal number of amphorae on multiple availability zones. - New data model for Heat template. This defines the properties of the auto-scaling cluster (alarms, scaling policies, minimal/maximal number of amphorae, etc.). [P2] It also defines the availability zones and the association of amphora to Distributor and Heat stack. - Add operator API to support configuration of an auto-scaled cluster. Add default configuration. * Network driver changes - Support the creation, connection, and configuration of the various networks and interfaces as described in high-level topology' diagram. - [P2] Allow secure isolated communication on the multi-tenant Distributor network. In particular, amphorae of different tenants must not be able to communicate with each other. - Support network isolation for the amphora back-end connections. Only the amphorae of particular clusters should be able to communicate on the tenant's network. While this needs to be handled with current topologies, there needs to be support for more than two amphorae and for dynamically adding amphorae to the tenant network. For example, the operator may need to allocate a range of amphora IPs on the tenant's network. (@TODO Might need to extend LBaaS API) - @TODO TBD; incomplete * Ceilometer and amphora health-monitoring support - Develop a configurable load-metric for amphorae that is able to indicate an overloaded or under-loaded Amphora Cluster (requires scale-up or scale-down actions). Report the metric through Ceilometer and manage through Heat. Initial reference implementation will be based on CPU load. - [P2] Update Amphora image to support load reporting of HAProxy metrics (e.g., queue length). - Ceilometer configuration shall be done via Heat. Extend operator API to support this. Define default Ceilometer configuration. - Modify Health Manager to utilize Heat (rather than manage the amphora only directly). Heat should detect unhealthy amphorae (via `Neutron::HealthMonitor`), remove them and spawn replacement amphorae if needed (utilizing Octavia for configuration, as described above). Octavia should still monitor health aspect that are specific to the load-balancing services (@TODO define these; @TODO Should Heat check health on the management network or on another network). - Develop a configurable health-metric for amphorae that is able to indicate an unhealthy amphora (i.e., one that requires replacement) rather than indicate a cluster that must be scaled-up. [P2] Create a cluster health metric to be used by the Health Manager to determine the health of the load-balancing services. - [P2] Support a network-based load-metric for amphorae that is measured on the Distributor network (e.g., number of connections). - [P2] Support security (e.g., credentials and tenant isolation) for Ceilometer metrics. * Distributor support - *Note:* as mentioned above, the detailed design of the Distributor component will be described in a separate document). Some design considerations are highlighted below. - The Distributor should be supported similarly to an amphora; namely, have its own abstract driver. On the other hand, the Distributor should be multi-tenant to avoid excessive resource usage per loadbalancer and to allow for network or hardware-based solutions which are not deployable on-demand like amphorae. - For a reference implementation, add support for a Distributor image, based on a multi-tenant Linux LVS. The image should have pre-installed public keys to allow secure configuration by the Octavia controller. - Define a REST API for Distributor configuration (no SSH API). The API shall support: - Registration and de-registration of amphorae. - Add and remove a VIP (loadbalancer). - Spawn default Distributor on Octavia start. Manage health and life-cycle of Distributor. Create, connect, and configure Distributor network as necessary. - Create data model for the Distributor. - Extend the controller worker to (re-)configure the Distributor on creation/destruction of a new loadbalancer (add/remove loadbalancer VIP) and [P2] configure the distribution algorithm for the loadbalancer's Amphora Cluster. - Extend the controller worker to (re-)configure the Distributor on adding/removing amphorae from the cluster (i.e., in response to Heat/Nova call-backs). - Set default distribution algorithm of the reference implementation to Round-robin with L4 (per-flow) affinity and MAC forwarding (no NAT or TCP termination at the Distributor). [P2] Extend the provider API (conf. file or Neutron flavor) to support other settings. - [P2] Handle graceful amphora removal, where no new connection are forwarded to the amphora; however, during the grace period, existing connections are still forwarded to the removed amphora until all such connections close or until a specified timeout has passed (whichever is first). * Packaging - Extend Octavia installation scripts to create an instance of a Distributor APIs @TODO incomplete --------------------- * Distributor REST API -- @TODO TBD * Amphora REST API -- e.g., support configuration of connecting with Distributor(s) -- @TODO TBD * Octavia REST API -- e.g., support for asynchronous amphora creation/deletion events -- @TODO TBD * [P2] LBaaS API -- e.g., define desired QoS, affinity to back-end availability-zone, etc. -- @TODO TBD * Operator API -- @TODO incomplete - Topology to use - [P2] List of availability zones - Default availability and QoS requirements / default Heat template parameters for the Amphora Cluster stack + Min number of Amphora per load balancer Heat stack (`Heat::AutoScalingGroup::min_size`) + Max number of Amphora per load balancer Heat stack (`Heat::AutoScalingGroup::max_size`) + Desired capacity per load balancer Heat stack (`Heat::AutoScalingGroup::desired_capacity`) + CoolDown (scale-up) period of Amphora per load balancer Heat stack (`Heat::ScalingPolicy::cooldown`) + CoolDown (scale-down) period of Amphora per load balancer Heat stack (`Heat::ScalingPolicy::cooldown`) + Scale up CPU threshold (in percentage) (`Ceilometer::Alarm::threshold`) + Scale down CPU threshold (in percentage) (`Ceilometer::Alarm::threshold`) + Period in seconds for both scale up and scale down to check metric (`Ceilometer::Alarm::period`) * (`Ceilometer::Alarm::evaluation_periods`) - Unconfigurable (hard coded) + scaling_adjustment = +-1 ; (We assume that all scale-up / down are +-1 amphora per event) (`Heat::ScalingPolicy::scaling_adjustment`) + meter_name = average cpu-util ; start with this metric since it encapsulates all of the hard work' that the Amphra performs (e.g., ssl and/or other) (`Ceilometer::Alarm::meter_name == cpu_util`) (`Ceilometer::Alarm::statistic == avg`) + Scale down CPU threshold (in percentage) (`Ceilometer::Alarm::threshold`) Alternatives ------------ * Do all orchestration from Octavia. This is more similar to the VRRP implementation. Such an approach does puts an unnecessary burden on Octavia, which does not scale well. Furthermore, by using Heat we get more advanced auto-scaling options and enjoy new Heat features as they are implemented. * Do all orchestration from Heat. Heat supports (or soon will support) various life-cycle hooks to manage instances of auto-scale groups. On the other hand, Heat is agnostic to the application, so it would be difficult multi-step Octavia-specific flows. Since Heat is used to trigger the actions, it should be possible to implement a scalable Octavia solution by providing a scalable task/flow engine. Data model impact ----------------- * @TODO Incomplete. Some changes listed above. Need detailed schema once we agree on the above higher-level description of the system. * loadbalancer table - New topology type: Heat-AUTO-SCALED * Heat-Auto-Scaled loadbalancer ID Heat Stack ID * New table(s): Heat configuration Availability zones Map template to amphorae Map template to Distributor QoS configuration (alarm, scaling policies) HA configuration (min count, availability zones) * Amphora table - New column: `distributor_ip` -- amphora (unique) address on Distributor network - New column: `distributor_port`  neutron port on Distributor network - New column: `distributor_id` -- ID of Distributor instance that forwards to this amphora * New table: Distributor - ... Security impact --------------- * @TODO Incomplete. Some changes listed above. Need detailed description once we agree on the changes. * Security Groups / Authentication tokens - Allow authentication Header traffic on tenant net - Allow amphora peers (same cluster) to synchronize - Isolate traffic of other tenants - Isolate traffic on the LB management network between tenants * The Distributor and the Distributor network are multi-tenant. The rationale is that all traffic is external traffic before it reaches the amphora. This might not be true for some cases. For example, if LBaaS is used for internal tier-to-tier communication inside a tenant network. Some operators may want their loadbalancer's VIP to remain private or may need private (possibly overlapping) VIP addresses. In these cases, in order to accomplish auto-scale for this tenant we would need a separate dedicated Distributor instance or at least a dedicated Distributor network. A dedicated Distributor instance might consume too many resources per VIP, so should generally be avoided unless it is an absolute must. A dedicated Distributor network is a possibility, but considerably complicates neutron configuration and may also consume an unacceptable amount of resources for some operators. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- @TODO Performance Impact ------------------ @TODO Other deployer impact --------------------- @TODO Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- @TODO Work Items ---------- @TODO Dependencies ============ @TODO Testing ======= * Unit tests with tox. * Function tests with tox. Documentation Impact ==================== @TODO References ========== @TODO [6][] [7][] [8][] [9][] [10][] [11][] [P2]: http://"Items marked with [P2] refer to lower priority features to be designed / implemented only after initial release" [6]: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/base-image [7]: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/controller-worker [8]: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/amphora-driver-interface [9]: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/controller [10]: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/operator-api [11]: doc/main/api/haproxy-amphora-api.rst @TODO Sections progress check-list: * Distributor support *new* - [X] Distributor Image - [X] Distributor Driver - [X] Controller / Worker * Amphora Changes - [X] Amphora image - [ ] Data model - [X] Support asynchronous creation/removal * Drivers - [X] Compute Driver - [X] Network Driver - [X] Controller / Worker * Ceilometer - [X] Provide amphora utilization metrics - [X] Health Monitor Driver * APIs - [ ] LBaaS API - [X] Operator API (Octavia.conf) - [ ] Octavia REST API

commit_message:
Allow a fixed IP to be allocated to RedisVirtualIP

The overcloud stack now contains a parameter RedisVirtualFixedIPs which will
allow people to specify the IP address they would like to be assigned as a vip
used by Redis. This will allow people full control over what IPs are used as
VIPs during a deployment.

Change-Id: Ib24e62847c4ac43fcd2a09bc84b4a76e992add4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/19/352219/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[zmq] Eliminate GreenPool from GreenPoller

GreenPool is not really needed in GreenPoller and creates an overhead.

commit_message:
Correct reraising of exception

When an exception was caught and rethrown,
it should call 'raise' without any arguments
because it shows the place where an exception
occured initially instead of place where
the exception re-raised

Change-Id: I875d159c0c229c9637b9d95c1a91c4651daafc44

commit_message:
Add command notes

Swift has no "swift help SUBCOMMAND", some one don't know how to use
swift command, so I add these command notes.

commit_message:
Remove LVM config from openstack_hosts

The LVM configuration tasks/template are no longer needed in the
openstack_hosts role since they're already in the os_cinder role.
This patch removes the tasks and the lvm.conf template.

Partial-bug: 1615325
Change-Id: I09b2cd9a1eee9f8310783b7d6468963b21fee322
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts refs/changes/77/360077/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Nuke lbaas v1

v1 is not going to ship in Newton, the deprecation notice
been around for two cycles, and there is now a migration
script.

Also includes: Fix alembic migration env

The include_object() checking was missing, and also the inclusion
of all lbaas DB models

Co-Authored-By: Henry Gessau <gessau@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Adam Harwell <flux.adam@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I506949e75bc62681412358ba689cb07b16311b68

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # import mock from neutron.api.v2 import attributes from neutron import context as ncontext from neutron.plugins.common import constants from neutron_lbaas.drivers import driver_mixins from neutron_lbaas.extensions import loadbalancerv2 from neutron_lbaas.services.loadbalancer import constants as lb_const from neutron_lbaas.tests.unit.db.loadbalancer import test_db_loadbalancerv2 class DummyManager(driver_mixins.BaseManagerMixin): def __init__(self, driver): super(DummyManager, self).__init__(driver) self.driver = driver self._db_delete_method = None @property def db_delete_method(self): return self._db_delete_method def delete(self, context, obj): pass def update(self, context, obj_old, obj): pass def create(self, context, obj): pass class TestBaseManager(test_db_loadbalancerv2.LbaasPluginDbTestCase): def _setup_db_data(self, context): hm = self.plugin.db.create_healthmonitor( context, {'admin_state_up': True, 'type': lb_const.HEALTH_MONITOR_HTTP, 'delay': 1, 'timeout': 1, 'max_retries': 1}) lb = self.plugin.db.create_loadbalancer( context, {'vip_address': '10.0.0.1', 'vip_subnet_id': self.subnet_id, 'admin_state_up': True}) pool = self.plugin.db.create_pool( context, {'protocol': lb_const.PROTOCOL_HTTP, 'session_persistence': None, 'lb_algorithm': lb_const.LB_METHOD_ROUND_ROBIN, 'admin_state_up': True, 'healthmonitor_id': hm.id, 'loadbalancer_id': lb.id}) self.plugin.db.create_pool_member( context, {'address': '10.0.0.1', 'protocol_port': 80, 'admin_state_up': True}, pool.id) listener = self.plugin.db.create_listener( context, {'protocol_port': 80, 'protocol': lb_const.PROTOCOL_HTTP, 'admin_state_up': True, 'loadbalancer_id': lb.id, 'default_pool_id': pool.id, 'sni_container_ids': []}) return listener def setUp(self): super(TestBaseManager, self).setUp() self.context = ncontext.get_admin_context() self.driver = mock.Mock() self.driver.plugin = self.plugin self.manager = DummyManager(self.driver) network = self._make_network(self.fmt, 'test-net', True) self.subnet = self._make_subnet( self.fmt, network, gateway=attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED, cidr='10.0.0.0/24') self.subnet_id = self.subnet['subnet']['id'] self.listener = self._setup_db_data(self.context) class TestLBManager(TestBaseManager): def setUp(self): super(TestLBManager, self).setUp() self.manager._db_delete_method = self.plugin.db.delete_loadbalancer def test_success_completion(self): self.manager.successful_completion(self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer) lb = self.plugin.db.get_loadbalancer(self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer.id) self.assertEqual(constants.ACTIVE, lb.provisioning_status) self.assertEqual(lb_const.ONLINE, lb.operating_status) def test_success_completion_delete(self): self.plugin.db.delete_listener(self.context, self.listener.id) self.manager.successful_completion(self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer, delete=True) self.assertRaises(loadbalancerv2.EntityNotFound, self.plugin.db.get_loadbalancer, self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer.id) def test_failed_completion(self): self.manager.failed_completion(self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer) lb = self.plugin.db.get_loadbalancer(self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer.id) self.assertEqual(constants.ERROR, lb.provisioning_status) self.assertEqual(lb_const.OFFLINE, lb.operating_status) listener = self.plugin.db.get_listener(self.context, self.listener.id) self.assertEqual(constants.PENDING_CREATE, listener.provisioning_status) self.assertEqual(lb_const.OFFLINE, listener.operating_status) class TestListenerManager(TestBaseManager): """This should also cover Pool, Member, and Health Monitor cases.""" def setUp(self): super(TestListenerManager, self).setUp() self.manager._db_delete_method = self.plugin.db.delete_listener def test_success_completion(self): self.manager.successful_completion(self.context, self.listener) listener = self.plugin.db.get_listener(self.context, self.listener.id) self.assertEqual(constants.ACTIVE, listener.provisioning_status) self.assertEqual(lb_const.ONLINE, listener.operating_status) self.assertEqual(constants.ACTIVE, listener.loadbalancer.provisioning_status) # because the load balancer's original operating status was OFFLINE self.assertEqual(lb_const.OFFLINE, listener.loadbalancer.operating_status) def test_success_completion_delete(self): self.manager.successful_completion(self.context, self.listener, delete=True) self.assertRaises(loadbalancerv2.EntityNotFound, self.plugin.db.get_listener, self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer.id) def test_failed_completion(self): self.manager.failed_completion(self.context, self.listener) lb = self.plugin.db.get_loadbalancer(self.context, self.listener.loadbalancer.id) self.assertEqual(constants.ACTIVE, lb.provisioning_status) self.assertEqual(lb_const.OFFLINE, lb.operating_status) listener = self.plugin.db.get_listener(self.context, self.listener.id) self.assertEqual(constants.ERROR, listener.provisioning_status) self.assertEqual(lb_const.OFFLINE, listener.operating_status)

subject: Revert "[trove] Promote scenario tests to voting and gating"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-15 09:56:39.000000000', 'files': ['zuul/layout.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/d09b8b6a351b2b854f9167aefbe790e8e9a23e6a', 'message': 'Revert "[trove] Promote scenario tests to voting and gating"

This reverts commit f6ca83d972291a7dcb1762469dabc8e4d43a2f81.

With increased load on the CI system as we approach the N deadline,
the two jobs which were made voting are taking increasingly longer,
and are often timing out. A lot of work had been done early in the
cycle to streamline the jobs and we felt that this would have been
enough. But, given the number of failures, and the coming release
crunch, it may be time to make them non-voting again till we can
figure out how to improve them.

Change-Id: Ib512a2a0b00852b7c77e5326437f7f4b0dd5bc4f
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "[trove] Promote scenario tests to voting and gating"

This reverts commit f6ca83d972291a7dcb1762469dabc8e4d43a2f81.

With increased load on the CI system as we approach the N deadline,
the two jobs which were made voting are taking increasingly longer,
and are often timing out. A lot of work had been done early in the
cycle to streamline the jobs and we felt that this would have been
enough. But, given the number of failures, and the coming release
crunch, it may be time to make them non-voting again till we can
figure out how to improve them.

Change-Id: Ib512a2a0b00852b7c77e5326437f7f4b0dd5bc4f

commit_message:
Accept IPv6 RAs on the interface with the default route

Because neutron sets ipv6 forwarding settings, we stop accepting RAs
from IPv6-only host environments. This leads to a loss of external
connectivity, which is bad for zuul running tests and stuff.

Setting accept_ra to 2 will cause the RAs to be accepted.

(cherry picked from commit 85b1308be4f4107a9054037b1d7351f57f473a1f)

Conflicts:
	lib/neutron_plugins/services/l3

Closes-bug: #1616282

Change-Id: Ia044fff2a1731ab6c04f82aea47096b425e0c0a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/75/359975/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ensure IPv6 RAs are accepted on all interfaces # This is needed for neutron-based devstack clouds to work in # IPv6-only clouds in the gate. Please do not remove this without # talking to folks in Infra. sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra=2

commit_message:
Split multinode.yaml template

Split the template so we have a common template that we can re-use for
other scenarios.

Change-Id: I0adb03dcd57bcc8afdf6a612f9ba46c7340966f6

commit_message:
Lower the aes-xts-plain64 key_size to 256

Lowering the key_size to 256 will still exercise the code path
appropriately while being compatible with Barbican as a key
manager.

Change-Id: Id713da735164dcad773be62921de7f2dc5f22910
Related-Bug: #1514546

commit_message:
Add support for usages in the placement API

GET /resources_providers/{uuid}/usages returns a dictionary of resource
usage by resource class.

Change-Id: I3ad0d16594301635966bd9e9352bc3f1f29dab14
Partially-Implements: blueprint generic-resource-pools
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/43/329643/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # More interesting tests for usages are in with_allocations fixtures: - ConfigFixture defaults: request_headers: x-auth-token: admin tests: - name: fail to get usages for missing provider GET: /resource_providers/fae14fa3-4b43-498c-a33c-4a1d00edb577/usages status: 404 - name: create provider POST: /resource_providers request_headers: content-type: application/json data: name: a name status: 201 - name: check provider exists GET: $LOCATION response_json_paths: name: a name - name: get empty usages GET: $LAST_URL/usages request_headers: content-type: application/json response_json_paths: usages: {}

commit_message:
Check if c-vol is enabled

start_cinder from devstack doesn't always run the c-vol service
as it may be disabled (for example in a multi-node setup). The
log checks, however, were assuming it as always enabled.

Change-Id: Iab6156cc25f78e8f80b220bc93c2b2e4974a585a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/78/355678/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ensure_logs_exist c-api if is_service_enabled c-vol; then ensure_services_started c-vol ensure_logs_exist c-vol fi

commit_message:
Use osc_lib instead of cliff

Base classes of commands are defined in cliff,
but have been encapsulated again in osc-lib for
all plugin clients. So use osc-lib instead of
cliff.

Change-Id: I23020cc01aabda08741e7854f9d7e2fcc312c8bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cueclient refs/changes/42/335342/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from osc_lib.command import commandclass ListClustersCommand(command.Lister):class ShowClusterCommand(command.ShowOne):class CreateClusterCommand(command.ShowOne):
deleted_lines: from cliff import command from cliff import lister from cliff import showclass ListClustersCommand(lister.Lister):class ShowClusterCommand(show.ShowOne):class CreateClusterCommand(show.ShowOne):

commit_message:
Use osc-lib instead of openstackclient

osc-lib is a package of common support modules for writing
OSC plugins. All common functions, classes such as exceptions,
utils, logs and so on have been moved from openstackclient to
osc-lib.

So use osc-lib instead of openstackclient.

Change-Id: I5907dfdfc92b9d10c8940c12adf0c230650a2c4f

deleted_lines: from cueclient import utils from openstackclient.common import utils as oscutils

commit_message:
Now it is possible to filter /api/v1/graphs/ output

following filter parameters are possible:

/api/v1/graphs/?clusters_ids=cluster1,cluster2&fetch_related=1
/api/v1/graphs/?plugins_ids=plugin1
/api/v1/graphs/?releases_ids=release1,release2

/api/v1/graphs/?graph_types=my-graph-type

`fetch_related` option working only for 'cluster' level telling Nailgun to include
all graphs related to plugins enabled for this cluster and tis cluster's release.

Logic of work:
(releases OR plugins OR clusters) AND type

Change-Id: Ib1d6dcd4483451dc71a701beb13805098380e22f
Closes-Bug: #1606931
(cherry picked from commit 9c75a4db71505acb0d5cb100aabdc03699e3f507)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/22/354822/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import webfrom nailgun import utils @content def GET(self): """Get deployment graphs list with filtering. :returns: JSONized object. :http: * 200 (OK) * 400 (invalid object data specified) * 404 (object not found in db) :http GET params: * clusters_ids = comma separated list of clusters IDs * plugins_ids = comma separated list of plugins IDs * releases_ids = comma separated list of releases IDs * graph_types = comma separated list of deployment graph types * fetch_related = 0/1 bool value that enables fetching graphs related to clusters release and plugins (default=0/False) """ # process args clusters_ids = self.get_param_as_set('clusters_ids') if clusters_ids: clusters_ids = self.checked_data( validate_method=self.validator.validate_ids_list, data=clusters_ids ) plugins_ids = self.get_param_as_set('plugins_ids') if plugins_ids: plugins_ids = self.checked_data( validate_method=self.validator.validate_ids_list, data=self.get_param_as_set('plugins_ids') ) releases_ids = self.get_param_as_set('releases_ids') if releases_ids: releases_ids = self.checked_data( validate_method=self.validator.validate_ids_list, data=self.get_param_as_set('releases_ids') ) graph_types = self.get_param_as_set('graph_types') fetch_related = utils.parse_bool( web.input(fetch_related='1').fetch_related ) # apply filtering if clusters_ids or plugins_ids or releases_ids: entities = [] # all objects for which related graphs is fetched if clusters_ids: entities.extend( objects.ClusterCollection.filter_by_id_list( None, clusters_ids ).all() ) if plugins_ids: entities.extend( objects.PluginCollection.filter_by_id_list( None, plugins_ids ).all() ) if releases_ids: entities.extend( objects.ReleaseCollection.filter_by_id_list( None, releases_ids ).all() ) result = self.collection.get_related_graphs( entities, graph_types, fetch_related ) else: if graph_types: # and no other filters result = self.collection.filter_by_graph_types(graph_types) else: result = self.collection.all() return self.collection.to_list(result)
deleted_lines: :param obj_id: related model object ID :type obj_id: int|basestring

commit_message:
Fixes Neutron metadata parameters in THT

Changes include:
 - Adds missing parameter to enable DHCP Metadata networks, which is
   required to enable isolated or forced metadata via DHCP agent
 - Fixes isolated metadata parameter to use a boolean
 - Fixes regression where force metadata parameter was accidentally
   removed

Closes-Bug: 1613743

Change-Id: I08f907fe8a8e89e108351b84db33c4d9c004b957
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/87/355987/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NeutronEnableMetadataNetwork: default: false description: If True, DHCP provide metadata network. Requires either IsolatedMetadata or ForceMetadata parameters to also be True. type: boolean NeutronEnableIsolatedMetadata: default: false type: boolean NeutronEnableForceMetadata: default: false description: If True, DHCP always provides metadata route to VM. type: boolean - neutron::agents::dhcp::enable_force_metadata: {get_param: NeutronEnableForceMetadata} - neutron::agents::dhcp::enable_metadata_network: {get_param: NeutronEnableMetadataNetwork}

commit_message:
devstack: make NEXUSPATH configurable

the nexus path for RC is different. For example,
https://nexus.opendaylight.org/content/repositories/autorelease-1415/org/opendaylight/integration/distribution-karaf/0.5.0-Boron-RC1/
In order to test Boron-RC1, make NEXUSPATH configurable.

commit_message:
Fix volume upload-to-image for vhd disk-format

It was previously assumed that glance did not support qed
disk-format.
qemu-img still uses the legacy 'vpc' format name as a
parameter. When executing 'qemu-img convert', vhd was
being passed as a parameter which is invalid.

This fix adds 'vhd' to the valid disk formats and passes
'vpc' to 'qemu-img convert', which is correct use of the
command.

'vhdx' disk format was not included in the cherry pick as
it is not supported by Glance in stable/mitaka.

Change-Id: I24e6b78505a2c77b309c79ef11466c08bad1c50a
Closes-Bug: #1585612
(cherry picked from commit e815f56bd54548e98c45e19a95f80ffd51cc21f1)

added_lines: --- features: - Added support for vhd disk-format for volume upload-to-image.

commit_message:
Add cluster to cert commands

This patch will update the certificate api to use the term Cluster
instead of Bay.  Bay will still be supported, but will be deprecated
and removed in a future release.

Change-Id: Ie169162a743320813e636597240941b5dd59ded3
Implements: blueprint rename-bay-to-cluster

commit_message:
Bump rfc3986 to 0.2.2

rfc3986 0.2.2 includes fix the issue: valid URI characters are not
accepted.[1], so we need bump it to 0.2.2

[1]https://github.com/sigmavirus24/rfc3986/commit/459a40f1f59c6204182b9d010f68cb4b35dff828

commit_message:
[GATE UNBLOCK] Purge/reinstall broken package from the xenial base image

This change simply removes a package from the base container image via
a prep command to ensure "libssl1.0.0" installed is a valid version and
is using a release that is supported by the local mirrors.

Change-Id: I7933b6300df5a3aff91d49cfff0deb95896e4f84
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts refs/changes/86/359586/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # PURGE packages that need to be potentially downgraded # * The "libssl1.0.0" package is using a version that is not found on the mirror which is blocking # the installation of libssl-dev due to a dep conflict. To correct this issue the ahead package # is removed and then reinstalled to force a downgrade. dpkg --force-all -P libssl1.0.0 apt-get install -y {{ lxc_cache_install_debconf }} --reinstall libssl1.0.0

commit_message:
Accept IPv6 RAs on the interface with the default route

Because neutron sets ipv6 forwarding settings, we stop accepting RAs
from IPv6-only host environments. This leads to a loss of external
connectivity, which is bad for zuul running tests and stuff.

Setting accept_ra to 2 will cause the RAs to be accepted.

(cherry picked from commit 85b1308be4f4107a9054037b1d7351f57f473a1f)

Conflicts:
	lib/neutron_plugins/services/l3

Closes-bug: #1616282

Change-Id: Ia044fff2a1731ab6c04f82aea47096b425e0c0a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/74/359974/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Ensure IPv6 RAs are accepted on all interfaces # This is needed for neutron-based devstack clouds to work in # IPv6-only clouds in the gate. Please do not remove this without # talking to folks in Infra. sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra=2

subject: Don't maintain user_id and project_id in context
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-18 23:37:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/39747e5f4618fc66360d6d46a8a2ed1d3cbed857', 'message': "Don't maintain user_id and project_id in context

The user_id and project_id are being provided to the base oslo.context
class which sets them on the user and tenant attributes. In future
oslo.context will provide the user_id and project_id parameters itself.

By force setting user_id and project_id on the context we override the
user and project params that were set in the base class with None
values.

For now make the user_id and project_id parameters renames of the base
class properties and then when oslo.context catches up we can simply
remove these properties. Having these as properties is consistent with
most other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I9cd3c1b1121011156e78388b6beaac0253324e22
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-08-18 23:40:13.000000000', 'files': ['nova/context.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6376bd251c632045cb0be685767b563f0397d58e', 'message': "Don't maintain user_id and project_id in context

class which sets them on the user and tenant attributes. In future
oslo.context will provide the user_id and project_id parameters itself.

By force setting user_id and project_id on the context we override the
user and project params that were set in the base class with None
values.

For now make the user_id and project_id parameters renames of the base
class properties and then when oslo.context catches up we can simply
remove these properties. Having these as properties is consistent with
most other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I9cd3c1b1121011156e78388b6beaac0253324e22
"}]
commit_message:
Don't maintain user_id and project_id in context

The user_id and project_id are being provided to the base oslo.context
class which sets them on the user and tenant attributes. In future
oslo.context will provide the user_id and project_id parameters itself.

By force setting user_id and project_id on the context we override the
user and project params that were set in the base class with None
values.

For now make the user_id and project_id parameters renames of the base
class properties and then when oslo.context catches up we can simply
remove these properties. Having these as properties is consistent with
most other OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I9cd3c1b1121011156e78388b6beaac0253324e22
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/42/357542/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # FIXME(dims): user_id and project_id duplicate information that is # already present in the oslo_context's RequestContext. We need to # get rid of them. @property def project_id(self): return self.project @project_id.setter def project_id(self, value): self.project = value @property def user_id(self): return self.user @user_id.setter def user_id(self, value): self.user = value
deleted_lines: # FIXME(dims): user_id and project_id duplicate information that is # already present in the oslo_context's RequestContext. We need to # get rid of them. self.user_id = user_id self.project_id = project_id

commit_message:
Use OVOs to set errors in manage volume/snapshot

Currently when we are managing volumes and snapshots and we run into an
error that requires changing the status to error we don't make use of
the OVO instances we already have and instead pass just the id to a
helper function that in some cases retrieves the resource again fro the
DB before doing the update.

This patch leverages the OVO instance we already have to consolidate
both helper methods -error_out_volume and error_out_snapshot- into using
error_out method.

Doing this not only simplifies the code but it also removes one extra DB
query.

Change-Id: I8d3b47dd71ee616bf00ba98ad1da0935356ebe74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/68/353068/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: flow_common.error_out(result) LOG.error(_LE("Snapshot %s: create failed"), result.id) flow_common.error_out(snapshot_ref, reason=_("Volume driver %s " "not initialized.") % driver_name)
deleted_lines: flow_common.error_out_snapshot(context, self.db, snapshot_id) LOG.error(_LE("Snapshot %s: create failed"), snapshot_id) snapshot_id = snapshot_ref['id'] flow_common.error_out_snapshot(context, self.db, snapshot_id, reason=_("Volume driver %s " "not initialized.") % driver_name)

commit_message:
Remove thirdparty from tox.ini

Since the change Ib5e24e19bcba9808a9f49fe7f328668df77fe4f9 , the
directory thirdparty has been removed. So we don't need to specify
it on tox.ini anymore.

Change-Id: I7eddcb975ebf20a78920acd6f48ba8260f6cb75a

commit_message:
Bump osc-lib to 1.0.2

osc-lib upper than 1.0.0 is supposed to be stable.
So for other projects to use stable osc-lib, bump
osc-lib to the latest 1.0.2 .

Change-Id: I095209c241876c6ab48595962e07144fc5cc34a6

Support condition for resource

Support condition section in resource definition.

Blueprint: support-conditions-function
Closes-Bug: #1605485

AWSTemplateFormatVersion: 2010-09-09 Parameters: env_type: Default: test Type: String AllowedValues: [prod, test] flavor: Type: String image: Type: String Conditions: Prod: {"Fn::Equals" : [{Ref: env_type}, "prod"]} Resources: net: Type: OS::Neutron::Net subnet: Type: OS::Neutron::Subnet Properties: network: {Ref: net} cidr: 10.10.10.0/24 test_server: Type: OS::Nova::Server Properties: image: {Ref: image} flavor: {Ref: flavor} networks: - subnet: {Ref: subnet} vol_attach: Type: OS::Cinder::VolumeAttachment Condition: Prod Properties: instance_uuid: {Ref: test_server} volume_id: {Ref: my_volume} mountpoint: /dev/vdh my_volume: Type: OS::Cinder::Volume Condition: Prod Properties: size: 1 ''' hot_template = ''' heat_template_version: 2016-10-14 parameters: flavor: type: string image: type: string env_type: default: test type: string constraints: - allowed_values: [prod, test] conditions: prod: {equals : [{get_param: env_type}, "prod"]} resources: net: type: OS::Neutron::Net subnet: type: OS::Neutron::Subnet properties: network: {get_resource: net} cidr: 20.10.10.0/24 test_server: type: OS::Nova::Server properties: image: {get_param: image} flavor: {get_param: flavor} networks: - subnet: {get_resource: subnet} vol_attach: type: OS::Cinder::VolumeAttachment condition: prod properties: instance_uuid: {get_resource: test_server} volume_id: {get_resource: my_volume} mountpoint: /dev/vdh my_volume: type: OS::Cinder::Volume condition: prod properties: size: 1 ''' class CreateUpdateResConditionTest(functional_base.FunctionalTestsBase): def setUp(self): super(CreateUpdateResConditionTest, self).setUp() def res_assert_for_prod(self, resources): self.assertEqual(5, len(resources)) res_names = [res.resource_name for res in resources] self.assertIn('net', res_names) self.assertIn('subnet', res_names) self.assertIn('test_server', res_names) self.assertIn('vol_attach', res_names) self.assertIn('my_volume', res_names) def res_assert_for_test(self, resources): self.assertEqual(3, len(resources)) res_names = [res.resource_name for res in resources] self.assertIn('net', res_names) self.assertIn('subnet', res_names) self.assertIn('test_server', res_names) self.assertNotIn('vol_attach', res_names) self.assertNotIn('my_volume', res_names) def test_stack_create_update_cfn_template_test_to_prod(self): parms = {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref} stack_identifier = self.stack_create(template=cfn_template, parameters=parms) resources = self.client.resources.list(stack_identifier) self.res_assert_for_test(resources) parms = {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref, 'env_type': 'prod'} self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template=cfn_template, parameters=parms) resources = self.client.resources.list(stack_identifier) self.res_assert_for_prod(resources) def test_stack_create_update_cfn_template_prod_to_test(self): parms = {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref, 'env_type': 'prod'} stack_identifier = self.stack_create(template=cfn_template, parameters=parms) resources = self.client.resources.list(stack_identifier) self.res_assert_for_prod(resources) parms = {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref, 'env_type': 'test'} self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template=cfn_template, parameters=parms) resources = self.client.resources.list(stack_identifier) self.res_assert_for_test(resources) def test_stack_create_update_hot_template_test_to_prod(self): parms = {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref} stack_identifier = self.stack_create(template=hot_template, parameters=parms) resources = self.client.resources.list(stack_identifier) self.res_assert_for_test(resources) parms = {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref, 'env_type': 'prod'} self.update_stack(stack_identifier, template=hot_template, parameters=parms) resources = self.client.resources.list(stack_identifier) self.res_assert_for_prod(resources) def test_stack_create_update_hot_template_prod_to_test(self): parms = {'flavor': self.conf.minimal_instance_type, 'image': self.conf.minimal_image_ref, 'env_type': 'prod'} stack_identifier = self.stack_create(template=hot_template, parameters=parms) resources = commit_message:
Update g-r and u-c for glance store rel 0.18.0

There was an important bug 1614307 found in VMware backend store that
lead to upload/snapshot failures. See change
I7a85ed1e2de1d5662f949bfa5307ed3c35ebe558 for more details.

This bump will clean things up.

Change-Id: Ia2026f438b359a059ed37ccbf3baece698f75c42
Depends-On: I7d96be6d3a09dd810842edea1548af632a161163
Related-Bug: 1614307

commit_message:
Add Pros/Cons docs for global cluster consideration

This comes from discussion in Bristol Hackathon (Feb 2016).
Currently Swift has a couple of choices (Global Cluster and Container
Sync) to sync the stored data into geographically distributed locations.

This patch adds the summary of the discussion comparing between
Global Cluster and Container Sync to enable operators to know which
functionality fits their own use case.

And, to be fairness with container-sync, this patch moves global
cluster docs into overview_global_cluster.rst from admin_guide.rst.

Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistair.coles@hpe.com>

Change-Id: I624eb519503ae71dbc82245c33dab6e8637d0f8b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/82/304382/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ------------------------------------------------- Geographically Distributed Cluster Considerations ------------------------------------------------- When you are trying to deploy Swif cluster into geographically distributed location, you can choose a couple of options, :doc:`overview_global_cluster` (Global Cluster), :doc:`overview_container_sync` (Container Sync), to get the functionality. Here, we have a table to describe the pros/cons of the choices for you which stuff you prefer to reference on your use case. +------+------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | | Global Cluster | Container Sync | +======+================================================+==========================================================================+ | Pros | - Location control via policy | - Better hardware segregation (cluster isolation) | | | - Operator centric config (user chooses policy)| - User centric location control ("local hosting") | | | - Optimistic WAN get | - Better onboarding capabilities (easy to sync with other Swift services)| | | - Cross container features/behaviors well known| - Allows to distribute the cluster management between teams | | | - Ops replication monitoring/throttling | | +------+------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | Cons | - Region ring management shared ops | - Current implementation sucks (is now working to fix) | | | - Account/Container updates via WAN | - User centric control may be a headache for the ops | | | - All Accounts/Conttianers spans global spaces | - Cross container features isolated (need to be setup for each container)| | | - No "read repair/replicate" | - Needs redundant replicas for each cluster | | | - EC is now ongoing work | - Simple EC scheme | +------+------------------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------------------------------------+
deleted_lines: ----------------------------------- Geographically Distributed Clusters ----------------------------------- Swift's default configuration is currently designed to work in a single region, where a region is defined as a group of machines with high-bandwidth, low-latency links between them. However, configuration options exist that make running a performant multi-region Swift cluster possible. For the rest of this section, we will assume a two-region Swift cluster: region 1 in San Francisco (SF), and region 2 in New York (NY). Each region shall contain within it 3 zones, numbered 1, 2, and 3, for a total of 6 zones. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ read_affinity ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This setting makes the proxy server prefer local backend servers for GET and HEAD requests over non-local ones. For example, it is preferable for an SF proxy server to service object GET requests by talking to SF object servers, as the client will receive lower latency and higher throughput. By default, Swift randomly chooses one of the three replicas to give to the client, thereby spreading the load evenly. In the case of a geographically-distributed cluster, the administrator is likely to prioritize keeping traffic local over even distribution of results. This is where the read_affinity setting comes in. Example:: [app:proxy-server] read_affinity = r1=100 This will make the proxy attempt to service GET and HEAD requests from backends in region 1 before contacting any backends in region 2. However, if no region 1 backends are available (due to replica placement, failed hardware, or other reasons), then the proxy will fall back to backend servers in other regions. Example:: [app:proxy-server] read_affinity = r1z1=100, r1=200 This will make the proxy attempt to service GET and HEAD requests from backends in region 1 zone 1, then backends in region 1, then any other backends. If a proxy is physically close to a particular zone or zones, this can provide bandwidth savings. For example, if a zone corresponds to servers in a particular rack, and the proxy server is in that same rack, then setting read_affinity to prefer reads from within the rack will result in less traffic between the top-of-rack switches. The read_affinity setting may contain any number of region/zone specifiers; the priority number (after the equals sign) determines the ordering in which backend servers will be contacted. A lower number means higher priority. Note that read_affinity only affects the ordering of primary nodes (see ring docs for definition of primary node), not the ordering of handoff nodes. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ write_affinity and write_affinity_node_count ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This setting makes the proxy server prefer local backend servers for object PUT requests over non-local ones. For example, it may be preferable for an SF proxy server to service object PUT requests by talking to SF object servers, as the client will receive lower latency and higher throughput. However, if this setting is used, note that a NY proxy server handling a GET request for an object that was PUT using write affinity may have to fetch it across the WAN link, as the object won't immediately have any replicas in NY. However, replication will move the object's replicas to their proper homes in both SF and NY. Note that only object PUT requests are affected by the write_affinity setting; POST, GET, HEAD, DELETE, OPTIONS, and account/container PUT requests are not affected. This setting lets you trade data distribution for throughput. If write_affinity is enabled, then object replicas will initially be stored all within a particular region or zone, thereby decreasing the quality of the data distribution, but the replicas will be distributed over fast WAN links, giving higher throughput to clients. Note that the replicators will eventually move objects to their proper, well-distributed homes. The write_affinity setting is useful only when you don't typically read objects immediately after writing them. For example, consider a workload of mainly backups: if you have a bunch of machines in NY that periodically write backups to Swift, then odds are that you don't then immediately read those backups in SF. If your workload doesn't look like that, then you probably shouldn't use write_affinity. The write_affinity_node_count setting is only useful in conjunction with write_affinity; it governs how many local object servers will be tried before falling back to non-local ones. Example:: [app:proxy-server] write_affinity = r1 write_affinity_node_count = 2 * replicas Assuming 3 replicas, this configuration will make object PUTs try storing the object's replicas on up to 6 disks ("2 * replicas") in region 1 ("r1"). Proxy server tries to find 3 devices for storing the object. While a device is unavailable, it queries the ring for the 4th device and so on until 6th device. If the 6th disk is still unavailable, the last replica will be sent to other region. It doesn't mean there'll have 6 replicas in region 1. You should be aware that, if you have data coming into SF faster than your link to NY can transfer it, then your cluster's data distribution will get worse and worse over time as objects pile up in SF. If this happens, it is recommended to disable write_affinity and simply let object PUTs traverse the WAN link, as that will naturally limit the object growth rate to what your WAN link can handle.

commit_message:
Add mapping_populate command

Fetching users from LDAP requires creating public ids for them.
id_mapping_api does that. Creating public ids is slow, because it
requires performing N INSERTs for N users, and there is no way to
work around that. It leads to very slow responses to queries like
"list users".

By pre-creating these public ids we improve API users' experience.

Add keystone-manage mapping_populate command that creates id mapping entries
for users.

bp ldap-preprocessing
Partial-Bug: 1582585
Change-Id: I98f795854aee26f9e7f668372c47572d2b6d4f0f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/28/343028/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class PrepareLdap(BaseApp): """Preprocess entries from LDAP. This command should be run right after LDAP was configured in Keystone. It is not required to run it, though. It only improves the initial user experience. Another case when it should be ran is when many new users were added to LDAP. """ name = "prepare_ldap" def __init__(self): self.load_backends() def load_backends(self): drivers = backends.load_backends() self.identity_manager = drivers['identity_api'] @classmethod def add_argument_parser(cls, subparsers): parser = super(MappingEngineTester, cls).add_argument_parser( subparsers) parser.add_argument('--domain-id', default=None, required=True, help=("ID of the domain configured to use LDAP " "and that needs to be prepared")) def main(self): domain_id = CONF.command.domain_id # the purpose of the command is to improve user experience when # keystone was just configured to use LDAP or many new users were # added to LDAP. Keystone needs to discover them and save to # id_mapping_api backend. # We don't actually need to tackle id_mapping_api in order to get # entries there, because list_users does this anyway. That's why it # will be enough to just make the call below. self.identity_manager.list_users(domain_scope=domain_id)

commit_message:
Fix update of shared QoS policy

When user updates QoS policy which is globaly shared, it will be still
marked as globally shared even if this flag was not set explicitly
in update request.
For example, updating description of QoS policy will not change shared
flag to default value which is "False".

Co-Authored-By: Haim Daniel <hdaniel@redhat.com>

Conflicts:
	neutron/objects/rbac_db.py
	neutron/tests/api/test_qos.py

Change-Id: I2c59e71eae0bf2e73475bba321afc4aaa514b317
Closes-Bug: #1585373
(cherry picked from commit 3c27beb8c0fe9b511bae78412b0623835a81f63f)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/28/347028/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @test.idempotent_id('ee263db4-009a-4641-83e5-d0e83506ba4c') def test_shared_policy_update(self): policy = self.create_qos_policy(name='test-policy', description='', shared=True) self.admin_client.update_qos_policy(policy['id'], description='test policy desc2') retrieved_policy = self.admin_client.show_qos_policy(policy['id']) retrieved_policy = retrieved_policy['policy'] self.assertTrue(retrieved_policy['shared']) self.admin_client.update_qos_policy(policy['id'], shared=False) retrieved_policy = self.admin_client.show_qos_policy(policy['id']) retrieved_policy = retrieved_policy['policy'] self.assertFalse(retrieved_policy['shared'])

commit_message:
Don't use config option sqlite_db

Config option sqlite_db is deprecated in
0a1bae9859079fb21a03716be947c5f1da6db0a2, and deprecate
argument sqlite_db in method set_defaults in
18d26125d02c8a017d8541339737981bf242616b, Glance doesn't
use config option sqlite_db's value, but config option
connection instead. For more details about sqlite connection
string, please see:
http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_1_0/core/engines.html#sqlite

Change-Id: I6eadd9d0c3c53d1c8a1afb441d5bdf647f4925e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/28/355728/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: options.set_defaults(CONF, connection='sqlite://')

commit_message:
NodeAssignment handler should return valid json

Fuel-Client expects valid json for all put and post
requests, so this patch fixes regress introduced by
patch: Ia3da3bd809bcca923d53666eca54def78c995f65

Change-Id: I6066e21504bb39e580609db14e1a4e5ea7d13258
Closes-Bug: #1606211

commit_message:
Now it is possilble to upload deployment graph via CLI

Also fixed fail in case if post request returns 204
also supported upload from directory.
the target dir should contain files: metadata.yaml and tasks.yaml

$ fuel2 graph upload --env 1 --file new_graph.yaml
$ fuel2 graph upload --release 1 --dir /var/data/graphs/provision -t provision

Now accepting two structure formats wrapped into the YAML:
1. {'tasks': [], 'metadata': {}, ....}
2. [{id: 'task1', ...}, {id: 'task2', ...}]

Change-Id: I5b5fc8c2733d0bc6bc31fb3a9e3d632b6e429ce7
Closes-Bug: #1615849

commit_message:
Now /graphs/execute/ handler is used to execute graph

$ fuel2 graph execute --env 1 [--nodes 1 2 3] [--graph_types gtype1 gtype2] [--task-names task1 task2] [--force] [--dry-run]
now calling brand new:
/api/v1/graphs/execute/
handler that using the Transactions Manager.

Also now it is possible to call:

$ fuel2 graph execute --force
to enforce execution of tasks without skipping.

$ fuel2 graph execute --task-names task1 task2
to run only specific tasks ignoring dependancies.

DocImpact
Change-Id: Iafc59c60a1ebce4a360ce1faa00a27ab320fa90b
Implements: blueprint graph-concept-extension

added_lines: cluster_deploy_api_path = "graphs/execute/" def execute(self, env_id, nodes=None, graph_type=None, dry_run=False): request_data = {'cluster': env_id} request_data['nodes'] = map(str, nodes) request_data['graph_type'] = graph_type request_data['dry_run'] = True deploy_data = self.connection.post_request( self.cluster_deploy_api_path, request_data )
deleted_lines: cluster_deploy_api_path = "clusters/{env_id}/deploy/" def execute(self, env_id, nodes, graph_type=None, dry_run=False): put_args = [] put_args.append("nodes={0}".format(",".join(map(str, nodes)))) put_args.append(("graph_type=" + graph_type)) put_args.append("dry_run=1") url = "".join([ self.cluster_deploy_api_path.format(env_id=env_id), '?', '&'.join(put_args)]) deploy_data = self.connection.put_request(url, {})

subject: Fix iSCSI multipath cleanup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-05 18:35:49.000000000', 'files': ['os_brick/tests/initiator/test_linuxscsi.py', 'os_brick/initiator/linuxscsi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-brick/commit/53173f78efef17a8456e09354361d04aa7f7da04', 'message': 'Fix iSCSI multipath cleanup

Cleanup order for multipath in remove_multipath_device should be:
- Flush multipath (multipath -f device)
- Flush blockdev devices (blockdev --flushbufs device)
- Remove paths

But now we have:
- Flush blockdev devices (blockdev --flushbufs device)
- Flush multipath (multipath -f device)
- Remove paths

This patch sets the right order.

Closes-Bug: #1502999
backport: liberty
Change-Id: If9dc8f3450ed473393bdb76fe34d5ab78cf9306c
'}]
commit_message:
Fix iSCSI multipath cleanup

Cleanup order for multipath in remove_multipath_device should be:
- Flush multipath (multipath -f device)
- Flush blockdev devices (blockdev --flushbufs device)
- Remove paths

But now we have:
- Flush blockdev devices (blockdev --flushbufs device)
- Flush multipath (multipath -f device)
- Remove paths

This patch sets the right order.

Closes-Bug: #1502999
backport: liberty
Change-Id: If9dc8f3450ed473393bdb76fe34d5ab78cf9306c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/34/231134/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
